question: Pine with brittle cube-like decay in heartwood and hoof-shaped red-brown perennial bracket - which fungus?
optionB: Ganoderma applanatum
learn: Fomitopsis pinicola causes brown rot in conifers producing distinctive reddish-brown hoof-shaped perennial brackets
whyMatters: Common on pine spruce fir. Brackets hard woody. Resinous appearance. Causes cubical brown rot typical of brown-rot fungi. Weakens stem
deepDive:
Fomitopsis pinicola: COMMON NAME - Red-belted polypore (UK) or Red-belted conk (US).
HOSTS - Conifers primary - pine spruce fir larch. Occasionally broadleaves. Dead and living trees.
BRACKETS - Perennial hoof-shaped or semicircular. Hard woody. Upper surface grey-brown to black often with distinctive red-brown margin or band when growing. Resinous varnished appearance. Pore surface white to cream. 10-40cm wide.
LOCATION - Usually on trunk at wounds broken branches. Can be basal or higher.
DECAY TYPE - Brown rot. Removes cellulose and hemicellulose leaves lignin. Wood becomes brown brittle cubes. Characteristic cubical cracking pattern.
PROGRESSION - Relatively slow for brown rot. Brackets persist for years adding layers. Decay advances through heartwood.
FAILURE MODE - Sudden brittle snap typical of brown rot. Minimal warning. Stem failure at decay location.
IDENTIFICATION - Hoof-shaped perennial bracket red-brown margin conifer host brown cubical decay. Distinctive combination.
Growth rings: Brackets show annual growth rings. Each ring equals one growing season. Useful for estimating infection age minimum.
Ecological role: Important deadwood decomposer. Saproxylic habitat. Indicator species of old-growth forests in some regions.
Assessment implications: BROWN ROT equals BRITTLE FAILURE risk. Wood snaps rather than bends. Sudden catastrophic failure mode. STEM LOCATION - If bracket high on stem assess drop zone. If basal assess windthrow potential. SHELL THICKNESS - Measure remaining sound wood. Brown rot reduces strength dramatically even with thick shell. More concerning than white rot of similar extent.
Management: BROWN ROT requires conservative assessment. Accept lower residual strength than white rot. REMOVE if over high-value targets and decay extensive. REDUCE LOADING if retention considered. Crown reduction lessen forces. MONITOR closely. Brown rot progresses and failure is sudden.
Recognition: RED-BROWN MARGIN when fresh (not always visible on old brackets). HOOF SHAPE. CONIFER HOST. Hard woody texture.
Similar fungi: FOMES FOMENTARIUS - Grey throughout. No red-brown. Different hosts (broadleaves). GANODERMA - Brown rot in some cases but appearance very different. Pore surface different. PHAEOLUS - Brown rot fungus but annual bracket soft when fresh different appearance

question: Hardwood stump with thin grey fan-like brackets with white margins causing selective delignification - identify:
optionB: Bjerkandera adusta
learn: Schizophyllum commune produces distinctive fan-shaped brackets with split gills and causes white rot with selective lignin degradation
whyMatters: Common cosmopolitan fungus. Found on dead hardwood. Distinctive split gills. Usually saprophytic on dead wood. White rot decomposer
deepDive:
Schizophyllum commune: COMMON NAME - Split-gill mushroom.
HOSTS - Many hardwood species. Dead wood primarily. Stumps logs branches. Occasionally wounds on living trees. Cosmopolitan worldwide distribution.
BRACKETS - Small 1-5cm thin fan-shaped or semicircular. Grey-brown to white. Upper surface hairy.
DISTINCTIVE FEATURE - Underside has split gills (look like gills but each is split lengthwise). Unique identification feature. Gills grey to purple-brown.
TEXTURE - Leathery tough when dry. Revives when wet. Can dry and rehydrate repeatedly.
DECAY TYPE - White rot. Selective delignification initially. Removes lignin first cellulose follows later.
OCCURRENCE - Usually abundant on dead wood. Multiple brackets. Can cover extensive areas.
ROLE - Saprophytic decomposer. Rarely pathogenic. Breaks down deadwood. Ecological value.
IDENTIFICATION - Split gills diagnostic. Nothing else has this feature. Fan shape small size grey color support ID.
Habitat: DEADWOOD - Stumps fallen logs dead branches. LIVING TREES - Occasionally colonizes wounds but rarely causes significant decay in living tissue. More opportunistic on dead tissue. WIDESPREAD - Found in forests gardens parks. Common and easily overlooked.
Recognition: Look at UNDERSIDE. SPLIT GILLS unique. Each gill longitudinally split creating distinctive appearance.
Compare similar species: STEREUM - Causes white rot has smooth pore surface (not gills). Different appearance. TRAMETES - Pores not gills. White rot fungi but different structure. BJERKANDERA - Pores not gills. Grey color similar but structure different.
Significance: Usually INSIGNIFICANT as pathogen. Important as deadwood decomposer. Abundant common part of ecosystem. If found on living tree usually at dead tissue not causing significant living tissue decay.
Management: USUALLY NONE NEEDED. Saprophytic on dead wood. If on living tree assess wound and surrounding tissue. Schizophyllum itself rarely concern.
Research interest: DESICCATION TOLERANCE - Can survive extreme drying. Rehydrates and resumes growth. Unusual adaptation. GENETICS - One of first fungi with genome sequenced. Model organism for fungal research.
Medicinal interest: SCHIZOPHYLLAN - Polysaccharide from S. commune. Research into medical applications. Anti-tumor properties studied. Not relevant to tree management but interesting biology

question: Two co-dominant stems showing counterflexing (moving in opposite directions) and cracks on opposite sides suggest:
optionB: Torsional loading and progressive failure of the union
learn: Counterflexing creates torsional (twisting) loads on the union causing cracks to propagate on opposite sides as stems twist relative to each other
whyMatters: Each stem responds independently to wind. Differential movement creates twisting forces at union. Cracks initiated on opposite sides. Progressive failure mechanism. Dangerous configuration
deepDive:
Torsional loading in unions: MECHANISM - Two co-dominant stems sway independently in wind. Out-of-phase movement creates relative rotation. Union experiences twisting (torsion) loads. Different from simple bending.
CRACK PATTERN - Cracks appear on OPPOSITE sides of union. Not same side as in simple bending failure. Spiral or helical progression possible. Propagate with each loading cycle.
COUNTERFLEXING - Visible movement where stems bend in opposite directions simultaneously. Creates scissor-like motion at union. Extremely high stress.
INCLUDED BARK common in these configurations. Weak plane exists. Torsion exploits weakness.
Detection: OBSERVE IN WIND - Watch stems during moderate wind. Do they move independently? Opposite directions? CRACKS ON OPPOSITE SIDES - Diagnostic pattern. Suggests torsional loading not simple bending. SOUND - May hear creaking groaning during movement. Active failure in progress.
Risk factors: LARGE STEMS - Heavy. High momentum. Greater forces on union. NARROW ANGLE - V-shaped union concentrates stress. ASYMMETRIC CROWNS - Different wind loading on each stem. Encourages counterflexing. INCLUDED BARK - Reduces torsional resistance. No wood connection.
Assessment urgency: COUNTERFLEXING plus CRACKS equals CRITICAL HAZARD. Active progressive failure. Imminent collapse possible. IMMEDIATE action required. Do not delay. Failure can occur any time especially during wind.
Management: EMERGENCY REMOVAL typically required. Union integrity severely compromised. BARRIERS IMMEDIATELY - Exclude targets from fall zone until removal completed. CAREFUL REMOVAL - Tree may fail during operations. Extra safety precautions. May require specialized rigging. CABLING NOT APPROPRIATE - Cannot reliably prevent torsional failure. Cable may increase loading. Don't attempt to stabilize.
Contrast with simple bending: BENDING FAILURE - Cracks on ONE side (tension side). Both stems move together. Simpler loading pattern. TORSIONAL FAILURE - Cracks on OPPOSITE sides. Stems move independently. Complex loading. MORE DANGEROUS.
Prevention: STRUCTURAL PRUNING YOUNG - Remove co-dominant stems early. Establish single leader. REDUCE PROBLEMATIC UNIONS - Before they become large and hazardous. Maintenance pruning to maintain hierarchy.
Prognosis: Unions showing counterflexing and opposite-side cracks have POOR prognosis. Failure likely. Retention rarely advisable.
Engineering perspective: TORSIONAL STRENGTH - Wood weaker in torsion than bending. Unions particularly vulnerable. Grain orientation matters. Included bark eliminates torsional resistance almost entirely

question: Declining alder beside water with soft fibrous white rot and thin annual brackets - which fungus?
optionB: Inonotus radiatus
learn: Inonotus radiatus causes white rot of alder producing thin annual orange-brown brackets typically near water
whyMatters: Specific to alder. Common in riparian zones. Annual brackets appear in autumn. Causes progressive decline and decay. Weakens stems
deepDive:
Inonotus radiatus: HOSTS - Alder primary (Alnus glutinosa common alder Alnus incana grey alder). Highly host-specific.
HABITAT - Typically near water. Riverbanks stream sides wet ground. Where alder naturally grows.
BRACKETS - Annual thin flexible when fresh. Orange-brown to rust-brown color. Hairy upper surface. Golden-brown pore surface. 3-10cm diameter.
APPEARANCE - Shelving or fan-shaped. Multiple brackets often in tiers or groups. Fresh brackets have golden appearance.
TIMING - Appear late summer to autumn. Decay and fall away over winter. New ones form each year.
DECAY TYPE - White rot. Soft fibrous pale decay. Lignin degradation. Cellulose fibers remain initially.
PROGRESSION - Causes progressive decay of stem and branches. Alder declines over years. Dieback occurs. Eventually death or structural failure.
LOCATION - On stems branches occasionally roots. Can be basal or at height.
IDENTIFICATION - Alder host thin orange-brown annual bracket riparian habitat. Combination diagnostic.
Impact on alder: COMMON - Widespread on alder in UK. Part of alder ecology. DECLINE - Infected trees show progressive dieback. May take years. Branch failure stem weakness. RIPARIAN CONCERN - Alders provide bank stabilization. Decay leads to failure potentially affecting erosion control. WINDTHROW - Weakened stems fail in storms. Along watercourses creates hazards.
Management considerations: RIPARIAN TREES - Alder along rivers important for ecology and bank stability. Balance decay risk with ecological value. REPLACEMENT - Consider planting new alders to replace declining infected trees. Maintain riparian function. HAZARD ASSESSMENT - Trees over paths roads buildings require evaluation. Failure risk increases with decay extent. NATURAL PROCESS - In natural woodland I. radiatus part of deadwood creation. Ecological role. Retention may be appropriate in low-risk settings.
Similar fungi: PHELLINUS - Also causes white rot of hardwoods but brackets are perennial woody. Different appearance. INONOTUS DRYADEUS - Causes butt rot of oak. Different host. Brackets larger darker resinous. INONOTUS HISPIDUS - On ash and other trees. Brackets very hairy (hispid) yellow-brown to rust. Different species.
Recognition: THIN ORANGE-BROWN annual brackets on ALDER near WATER equals I. radiatus. Alder specificity is key.
Ecology: I. radiatus part of alder deadwood cycle. Breaks down dead and dying alder. Creates habitat. Saproxylic value. Natural component of riparian ecosystems. Not viewed as problem in natural settings

question: Which winter feature distinguishes Field Maple (Acer campestre) from Sycamore and Norway Maple?
optionB: Smaller hairy buds and corky ridges on twigs
learn: Field maple has smaller hairy buds arranged oppositely and often develops distinctive corky wings on twigs
whyMatters: All three are maples with opposite buds but field maple is smaller with hairy buds and unique corky bark features on young twigs
deepDive:
Field Maple winter ID: BUDS - Opposite arrangement small 3-5mm hairy (downy) red-brown. Much smaller than sycamore or Norway maple buds.
TWIGS - Often develop CORKY RIDGES or wings. Distinctive feature. Grey-brown color. Irregular corky bark flakes on young twigs.
BARK - Grey-brown fissured developing corky texture. More pronounced in some individuals.
FORM - Small tree or large shrub typically. Native hedgerow tree. Smaller than sycamore or Norway maple generally.
Comparison: SYCAMORE (Acer pseudoplatanus) - Opposite green buds 5-10mm. No corky wings on twigs. Larger tree. NORWAY MAPLE (Acer platanoides) - Opposite red-brown buds 5-8mm. No corky wings. Larger tree. FIELD MAPLE - Opposite hairy buds 3-5mm. CORKY WINGS on twigs diagnostic. Smallest of the three.
Key diagnostic features: CORKY WINGS on twigs - Unique to field maple among UK maples. Not present on all specimens but common. HAIRY BUDS - Downy covering visible with close inspection. Other maples have smooth scales. SMALL SIZE - Both bud size and tree size smaller.
Additional clues: NATIVE SPECIES - Field maple is native to UK. Often in hedgerows and woodland edges. Common in southern England. SEEDS - In summer/autumn seeds have wings at nearly 180° (straight line). Reddish tinge. LEAVES - In summer leaves smaller than other maples 5-lobed rounded blunt lobes.
Similar species: Other maples rare in UK wild. Box elder (Acer negundo) has pinnate compound leaves. Japanese maples (Acer palmatum etc) ornamental different appearance.
Recognition: OPPOSITE BUDS plus CORKY TWIGS equals field maple. SMALL HAIRY BUDS support ID.
Habitat clue: Field maple in hedgerows ancient woodland edges field boundaries equals appropriate habitat. Less common in urban parks than sycamore or Norway maple.
Cultural importance: Native tree. Part of traditional hedgerows. Ancient woodland indicator in some regions. Wildlife value.
Field identification: CORKY WINGS definitive if present. SMALLER SIZE in all features. HEDGEROW HABITAT typical

question: Dead oak limbs with small shelving brackets showing lilac or violet tints - likely genus?
optionB: Ganoderma
learn: Trichaptum species produce thin leathery brackets with distinctive violet or purple tinges on dead hardwood
whyMatters: Common on dead oak and other hardwoods. Small brackets. Purple color diagnostic. White rot decomposers. Saprophytic on deadwood
deepDive:
Trichaptum species: COMMON SPECIES UK - Trichaptum abietinum on conifers. Trichaptum fuscoviolaceum on hardwoods (oak).
HOSTS - Dead wood primarily. Occasionally wounds on living trees but usually saprophytic. Oak beech birch others.
BRACKETS - Small thin 2-6cm diameter. Leathery flexible. Shelving or rosette-forming.
UPPER SURFACE - Grey to brown often with zones of different colors. Hairy or smooth.
DISTINCTIVE FEATURE - Pore surface or underside shows VIOLET PURPLE or LILAC tints especially when fresh. Fades with age. Pores or gill-like (varies by species).
COLOR - Purple/violet distinctive. Key identification feature. No other common UK fungi have this purple pore surface on small brackets.
TEXTURE - Tough leathery. Persists on dead wood for extended period.
DECAY - White rot. Breaks down lignin. Part of deadwood decomposition. Saprophytic role.
OCCURRENCE - Common on dead branches standing dead trees fallen logs. Often abundant.
Habitat: DEADWOOD - Primary substrate. Important deadwood decomposer. LIVING TREES - Rarely causes decay in living tissue. May be present at dead branch stubs.
Ecological role: SAPROXYLIC - Key deadwood fungus. Part of decomposition succession. Creates habitat. Food for invertebrates. Indicator species for deadwood quality in some contexts.
Recognition: SMALL LEATHERY BRACKETS with PURPLE/VIOLET UNDERSIDE on DEADWOOD equals Trichaptum. Color diagnostic.
Similar fungi: STEREUM - Purple when young but smooth surface not pores. Different structure. TRAMETES - Various colors but not purple. White rot fungi with pores. BJERKANDERA - Grey-brown not purple.
Management implications: INSIGNIFICANT as pathogen. Saprophytic. No concern for living tree health. Indicates deadwood present. If found on living tree usually at dead portions. NOT causing living tissue decay. Assess wound and surrounding tissue independently.
Research and ecology: Trichaptum part of fungal succession on deadwood. Early-middle colonizer. Follows pioneer species. Contributes to wood breakdown and nutrient cycling. Forest ecology.
Identification note: PURPLE COLOR fades with age and weathering. Fresh specimens show color best. Old brackets may be grey-brown. Check multiple brackets or dampen to bring out color.
Field observation: Common sight on dead oak branches. Part of natural deadwood community. Often overlooked but abundant once you know what to look for

question: A long vertical crack with no rolled edges showing fresh bright wood equals:
optionB: Acute failure event or sudden load spike requiring urgent assessment
learn: Fresh wood exposure and lack of callus prove crack is very recent - tree has not had time to respond indicating sudden failure or active propagation
whyMatters: Bright fresh wood means crack just formed or is actively extending. No healing response yet. Indicates structural emergency
deepDive:
Crack assessment - fresh vs old: FRESH ACUTE CRACK - Bright clean wood visible. Sharp edges. No callus tissue. No darkening or weathering. Bark cleanly separated. Recent formation (days to weeks). IMPLIES recent loading event or sudden failure in progress.
OLD STABLE CRACK - Darkened weathered wood. Callus rolls forming at edges. Bark healed over portions. Grey or brown discoloration. Stable for years.
Callus tissue development timeline: IMMEDIATE - Crack forms. Fresh wood exposed. WEEKS - Wood begins to darken. Surface weathers. MONTHS - Callus initiation at wound edges if tree responding. YEARS - Callus rolls progressively enlarge. Wound closure may occur if crack small and stable.
Implications of fresh crack: RECENT EVENT - Something happened recently to cause crack. Storm loading sudden exposure construction impact root loss other acute stress. ACTIVE PROPAGATION - Crack may be extending. Progressive failure. May continue to propagate with additional loading. STRUCTURAL EMERGENCY - Fresh cracks indicate compromised integrity. Urgent assessment required. Failure possible.
Investigation: DOCUMENT - Photograph measure. Establish baseline. HISTORY - Interview owner/manager. When did crack appear? Was there storm event? Any work done recently? Root damage? Exposure change? LOADING - Assess current loads. Crown size wind exposure recent weather. EXTENT - How much of circumference affected? How deep? Through stem or partial? CONSEQUENCES - What's below? People buildings vehicles? How urgent is risk? PROPAGATION CHECK - Mark crack ends. Re-inspect after wind event. Has it extended?
Management urgency: FRESH CRACK indicating ACUTE FAILURE equals IMMEDIATE PRIORITY. Do not delay. Barriers exclusion zone specialist assessment. Removal often necessary especially over targets. CANNOT assume crack will stabilize. May continue propagating.
Risk factors for continued propagation: LARGE CROWN - Heavy continued loading. WIND EXPOSURE - Frequent loading cycles. DECAY PRESENT - Associated internal decay. Crack may be symptom of more extensive hidden decay. LOADING CONTINUES - If cause of crack (wind exposure etc) continues crack will likely propagate further.
Monitoring if retained: MARK CRACK ENDS - Small marks on bark at top and bottom of crack. RE-INSPECT AFTER LOADING - After storms wind events. Has crack extended past marks? ASSUME PROPAGATION until proven otherwise. Act conservatively.
Contrast with old stable cracks: OLD CRACKS with good callus and no recent extension are LOWER RISK. Can often be monitored. FRESH CRACKS are ACTIVE and HIGH RISK. Require immediate intervention unless consequences minimal.
Prevention: Cannot prevent acute loading events. But can identify vulnerable trees beforehand. Structural assessment pruning to reduce loading in advance of storms. Proactive management

question: Declining alder beside watercourse with soft fibrous white rot and tarry lesions at base. Disease?
optionB: Armillaria mellea
learn: Phytophthora alni causes alder Phytophthora disease with characteristic bleeding cankers and progressive decline of riparian alder
whyMatters: Oomycete pathogen not true fungus. Causes bleeding cankers at root collar. Devastating to alder. Notifiable disease in UK. No cure. Riparian ecosystems affected
deepDive:
Alder Phytophthora (Phytophthora alni): PATHOGEN - Oomycete (water mold) not true fungus. Three varieties form P. alni complex.
HOSTS - Alder specific. Alnus glutinosa common alder primarily affected. Native UK species.
SYMPTOMS - Tarry dark reddish-brown bleeding lesions at root collar. Thin crowns yellowing leaves small leaves. Dieback progressive from top down. Cracked bark at lesions. Underlying wood dark stained.
PROGRESSION - Lesions girdle stem. Vascular tissue blocked. Crown declines over months to years. Death typical. Root rot also occurs.
SPREAD - Water-borne. Zoospores swim in water films. Rivers streams spread pathogen downstream. Wet soil conditions favor infection.
IMPACT - Devastating to riparian alder populations. Widespread in UK. Watercourse ecology affected. Alder important for nitrogen fixation bank stability.
Legal status: NOTIFIABLE DISEASE - Must report to APHA (Animal and Plant Health Agency). Legal requirement. Statutory notification.
Recognition: ALDER HOST beside WATER with BLEEDING CANKERS at base plus crown DECLINE equals Phytophthora alni. Combination diagnostic.
Comparison with other alder issues: INONOTUS RADIATUS - Causes white rot. Brackets present. No bleeding cankers. Different symptoms. ARMILLARIA - Causes root rot. White mycelial fans under bark. Rhizomorphs. Different symptoms. PHYTOPHTHORA - BLEEDING CANKERS diagnostic. No brackets. Tarry exudate. Specific appearance.
Management: NO CURE - Cannot treat infected trees. BIOSECURITY - Don't move water soil or plants from infected areas. Clean tools equipment. REMOVAL - Remove infected trees. Burn or bury on site. Don't chip or compost. REPLACEMENT - Replanting alder in infected areas risky. Consider resistant clones if available or alternative species. MONITORING - Inspect riparian alders regularly. Early detection. Report sightings.
Prevention: AVOID WATERLOGGING - Good drainage. Though alder naturally in wet sites. SPECIES SELECTION - Consider alternatives to alder in high-risk areas. Willow birch where appropriate. RESISTANT CLONES - Research into resistant alder genetics. Some clones show tolerance. Not widely available yet.
Ecological impact: RIPARIAN FUNCTION LOSS - Alder provides bank stabilization nitrogen fixation shade for streams. Loss significant. BIODIVERSITY - Alder supports specialist insects fungi. Ecosystem effects. LONG-TERM - Recovery uncertain. May be permanent loss from affected watercourses.
Species threatens: Widespread and persistent. One of most serious tree diseases in UK. Affects native species in native habitat. No effective control. Prognosis poor for affected alder populations

question: Black Poplar (Populus nigra) can be distinguished in winter by:
optionB: Large triangular leaf scars and deeply fissured burry bark
learn: Black poplar has characteristic large leaf scars burrs (rounded swellings) on trunk and deeply fissured dark bark distinguishing it from other poplars
whyMatters: Rare native tree. Large triangular leaf scars visible on thick twigs. Burrs on trunk distinctive. Deeply ridged bark. Often leaning form
deepDive:
Black Poplar winter ID: BUDS - Alternate large pointed 10-15mm sticky resinous. Similar to other poplars.
LEAF SCARS - LARGE triangular or shield-shaped. Prominent on thick twigs. Distinctive feature.
BARK - Deeply fissured dark grey-brown. Ridged and furrowed. Mature trees have very distinctive rugged bark.
BURRS - Rounded swellings bosses on trunk and branches. Characteristic of black poplar especially old trees.
FORM - Large tree. Often leaning or irregular form. Low heavy branches. Typically near water.
TWIGS - Thick yellowish to brown. Buds sticky.
Native status: NATIVE - True black poplar (P. nigra ssp. betulifolia) is native to UK and RARE. Many 'poplars' in UK are hybrid cultivars. TRUE NATIVE black poplar has distinctive features.
Rarity: CONSERVATION CONCERN - Native black poplar very rare. Thousands of hybrid poplars but few true natives. Protected where found.
Confusion species: HYBRID POPLARS - Various cultivars (Populus × canadensis hybrids etc). Often straighter form. Less distinctive bark. Planted commercially. LOMBARDY POPLAR (P. nigra 'Italica') - Cultivar of black poplar. Fastigiate columnar form. Distinctive shape but not native form. GREY POPLAR / WHITE POPLAR - Different bark (grey or white). Different leaf scars.
Recognition: BURRS on trunk LARGE LEAF SCARS DEEPLY FISSURED BARK NEAR WATER irregular form. Combination suggests TRUE BLACK POPLAR. Confirm species carefully - many hybrids.
Habitat: FLOODPLAINS - River valleys wet meadows. Tolerates flooding. Often alongside rivers. Natural habitat. AVENUES - Sometimes planted historically.
Recognition of age: Old black poplars very distinctive. Massive trunk. Deep fissures. Large burrs. Leaning irregular character. Veterans valuable.
Conservation: Native black poplar decline due to habitat loss hybrids replacing natives. Surveys to locate remaining natives. Protection and propagation efforts. Cuttings taken from verified native trees.
Identification challenge: DETERMINING TRUE NATIVE vs HYBRID difficult. Leaf shape in summer helpful. Winter features plus habitat plus form give clues. Expert verification recommended for confirmation.
Cultural importance: Historically important. Used for timber (lightweight). Landscape character. Ancient native populations valuable. Genetic resource

question: Young ash tree with pale buff annual brackets and early-stage white rot in the butt - which fungus?
optionB: Perenniporia fraxinea
learn: Perenniporia fraxinea causes white rot of ash butts despite the specific epithet it also affects beech and other species
whyMatters: Same fungus as Q126 but noting it affects ash as well as beech. Pale buff brackets. Basal location. White rot. Perennial brackets
deepDive:
Perenniporia fraxinea on ash: Despite 'fraxinea' (ash) in name this fungus is MORE COMMON on BEECH but does occur on ash. Causes white rot of roots and butt. Same characteristics as described in Q126. See Q126 for full details. Brackets perennial pale buff brown pore surface basal location. Progressive root and butt decay. Windthrow risk. Assessment and management identical to beech infections.
Host range: BEECH - Primary host most commonly affected. ASH - Secondary host. Less common than on beech but does occur. OTHER - Occasional reports on other hardwoods.
Species name misleading: Originally described from ash hence 'fraxinea'. Subsequently found to be more common on beech. Name retained despite primary host being beech. Confusion possible.
Recognition on ash: Same bracket appearance as on beech. Pale buff perennial pore surface brown. Basal location.
If on ash consider OTHER pathogens first: ARMILLARIA - More common on stressed ash especially with ash dieback. White mycelial fans diagnostic. KRETZSCHMARIA - Causes basal decay of ash. Diagnostic black stromata crusty patches. PERENNIPORIA - Less common on ash than above but does occur. Pale buff brackets diagnostic.
Management: Same as for beech. Serious butt rot. Assess root plate stability. Windthrow risk primary concern. Removal often necessary in high-risk settings. See Q126 for full management details.
Ash dieback context: Ash trees weakened by ash dieback more susceptible to secondary pathogens including Perenniporia Armillaria and others. Multiple stressors compound. Weakened trees cannot compartmentalize as effectively. Decay fungi colonize more readily.
Combined effect: Ash dieback causes crown decline and stem lesions. Secondary decay fungi attack weakened tissues. Further structural compromise. Tree mortality

question: Compression wood (reaction wood in conifers) visible on stem bend shows tree is:
optionB: Actively responding to mechanical stress
learn: Compression wood forms on the compression (lower) side of bends in conifers - indicates active adaptive growth response
whyMatters: Conifer equivalent of tension wood in broadleaves. Forms on lower/compression side. Pushes stem upward. Red-brown color denser wood. Successful adaptation. See Q83 for more detail
deepDive:
Compression wood identification: LOCATION - Lower side of leaning or bent conifer stems. Compression side during bending.
APPEARANCE - Darker color often reddish-brown. Denser than normal wood. Visible in growth rings as wider rings on compression side.
MICROSCOPIC - Rounded cells thicker walls higher lignin content intercellular spaces. Specialized tissue.
FUNCTION - PUSHES stem upward. Compression wood expands more than normal wood creating pushing force that straightens stem over time.
Why it forms: CONIFERS respond to lean by forming compression wood on LOWER side. BROADLEAVES form tension wood on UPPER side. Different mechanism same result - stem straightens. Both are adaptive responses.
Assessment implications: PRESENCE of compression wood POSITIVE SIGN - Tree is responding adapting managing its structural situation. ABSENCE in leaning tree CONCERNING - Suggests recent movement or tree unable to respond. Vigor question. SUCCESSFUL ADAPTATION indicated by compression wood formation. Tree has capacity to stabilize itself.
Recognition: In cross-section - ECCENTRIC GROWTH RINGS. Wider rings on compression side. In standing tree - Often visible as color difference. Reddish-brown zone on lower side of bend.
Species: All conifers form compression wood - pine spruce fir larch yew cedar others.
Analogous to tension wood: CONIFERS - Compression wood LOWER side PUSHES. BROADLEAVES - Tension wood UPPER side PULLS. Both correct lean achieve similar result through different cellular mechanisms.
Management: RECOGNIZE as adaptation NOT defect. Positive indicator. RETAIN trees showing compression wood - demonstrates active response and vigor. ASSESS lean stability but compression wood presence is encouraging sign.
Wood properties: COMPRESSION WOOD has different properties than normal wood - stronger in compression weaker in tension brittle less flexible. Relevant for timber but less so for tree assessment. Primary concern: Is tree responding? Compression wood proves it is.
See also Q83 and Q43 for detailed reaction wood mechanics

question: Mature oak with glossy chestnut-brown brackets exuding amber liquid and extensive root decay - identify:
optionB: Inonotus dryadeus
learn: Inonotus dryadeus causes root and butt rot of oak producing distinctive brown resinous-looking brackets that exude amber droplets
whyMatters: Specific to oak. Large brackets at base. Exudate diagnostic. White rot of roots. Serious anchorage implications. High windthrow risk
deepDive:
Inonotus dryadeus: COMMON NAME - Oak bracket or Weeping oak polypore.
HOSTS - Oak specific (Quercus spp.). Pedunculate oak and sessile oak. UK native oaks.
BRACKETS - Large 10-50cm diameter. Hoof-shaped or semicircular. Upper surface CHESTNUT-BROWN smooth often shiny or resinous appearance.
EXUDATE - AMBER to reddish DROPLETS ooze from bracket when fresh especially pore surface. Diagnostic feature. Droplets can be copious. Sticky resinous.
PORE SURFACE - White to cream when fresh browning with age. Bruises brown.
LOCATION - Basal - at root collar or ground level. Occasionally on exposed roots.
DECAY TYPE - White rot. Attacks roots root collar and lower stem. Extensive root plate decay typical.
FAILURE MODE - WINDTHROW. Root system compromised. Tree appears healthy above ground while roots failing. Sudden overturn possible.
IDENTIFICATION - Oak host chestnut-brown glossy bracket amber exudate basal location. Combination diagnostic.
Recognition: AMBER DROPLETS key diagnostic feature. Fresh brackets weep liquid. No other major oak decay fungus does this. GLOSSY CHESTNUT appearance distinctive.
Assessment implications: SERIOUS ROOT DECAY. Inonotus dryadeus causes extensive root plate failure. STABILITY ASSESSMENT CRITICAL. Probe root plate excavation consider pulling test. WINDTHROW PRIMARY RISK. Tree may appear healthy but root system failing. PRIORITY FOR INTERVENTION especially over high-value targets.
Similar fungi: GANODERMA - Also causes root rot of oak. Brackets different appearance (zonate darker brown). No amber exudate. MERIPILUS - Rosette brackets bruise black not brown. No amber exudate. Annual brackets soft when fresh. PERENNIPORIA - Pale buff not chestnut-brown. No exudate.
Management: ROOT PLATE ASSESSMENT essential. Visual may not reveal extent. REMOVAL often necessary. Retention very high risk unless consequences minimal. VETERAN OAK CONSIDERATION - Ancient oaks with I. dryadeus may be retained if targets allow. Ecological value high. Accept risk in appropriate contexts. MONITORING if retained - Frequent re-assessment. Stability can deteriorate rapidly.
Ecology: I. dryadeus part of oak deadwood ecology. Contributes to veteran oak habitat creation. Saproxylic value. In natural woodland part of processes. In managed landscape requires active risk management.
Prognosis: Progressive. Established infections continue. No cure. Root decay advances. Windthrow eventual outcome unless tree removed first

question: Rowan (Sorbus aucuparia) is identified in winter by:
optionB: Alternate buds with purple-grey downy terminal bud
learn: Rowan has alternate buds with distinctive purple-grey downy terminal bud plus smooth bark with horizontal lenticels
whyMatters: Small tree. Pinnate compound leaves in summer (not visible winter). Buds alternate. Terminal bud distinctive purple with downy scales. Common native tree
deepDive:
Rowan winter ID: BUDS - Alternate arrangement. Terminal bud large 10-15mm purplish-grey DOWNY (covered with fine hairs). Lateral buds smaller pressed to twig.
TWIGS - Slender grey-brown smooth. Lenticels (pale spots) visible.
BARK - Smooth grey-brown. Horizontal lenticels prominent. Remains smooth even when old (unlike some other trees that furrow).
FORM - Small tree or large shrub. Often multi-stemmed. Native to uplands and northern UK.
BERRIES - In autumn bright red-orange berry clusters. Often persist into winter (if not eaten by birds). Distinctive even when withered.
Key identification features: PURPLE-GREY DOWNY terminal bud diagnostic. Easy to recognize with practice. SMOOTH BARK with horizontal lenticels. ALTERNATE buds (not opposite).
Native status and habitat: NATIVE TREE - Mountain ash another common name. UPLAND - Common in Scotland northern England Wales. Also hedgerows woodlands. PIONEER SPECIES - Colonizes open ground. Short-lived (typically 60-100 years).
Similar species: OTHER SORBUS - Whitebeam (S. aria) has simple leaves (compound in rowan). Buds green. Service tree (S. domestica) rare buds larger sticky. ELDER (Sambucus nigra) - Opposite buds (not alternate). Pithy twigs. Different appearance. ASH - Opposite black buds. Rowan has alternate purple-grey buds. Different.
Recognition: PURPLE-GREY DOWNY bud plus ALTERNATE arrangement plus SMOOTH BARK equals rowan. Terminal bud distinctive.
Cultural significance: Native tree. Wildlife value - berries for birds. Traditional rowan associated with protection in folklore. Planted near houses. Ornamental value - autumn berries attractive.
Summer leaves pinnate: In summer rowan has compound pinnate leaves (many small leaflets along rachis). Distinctive. Helps ID but not visible in winter.
Related species: Sorbus genus. Whitebeams service trees rowans. Diverse genus. Rowan (S. aucuparia) most common and widespread in UK uplands

question: Large hoof-shaped perennial bracket on willow causing extensive white rot - which fungus?
optionB: Phellinus igniarius
learn: Phellinus igniarius causes white rot of willow and produces large perennial woody hoof-shaped brackets
whyMatters: Specific to willow and sometimes poplar. Large brackets. Perennial. Hard woody. White rot advances slowly but extensively. Weakens stems
deepDive:
Phellinus igniarius: HOSTS - Willow (Salix spp.) primary. Also poplar occasionally. HOST-SPECIFIC to these genera.
BRACKETS - Large hoof-shaped or semicircular. Perennial hard woody. 10-40cm+ diameter. Upper surface grey-brown to black often cracked. Concentrically zoned. Pore surface grey-brown.
LOCATION - Usually on stems and branches. Can be basal or at height.
DECAY TYPE - White rot. Slow but extensive. Heartwood primarily but can extend. Wood becomes pale soft stringy fibrous.
PROGRESSION - Very slow. Brackets can be decades old adding layers annually. Decay advances over many years.
FAILURE MODE - Stem snap or branch failure. Decay weakens structure progressively.
IDENTIFICATION - Hoof-shaped grey-black perennial bracket on willow. Large size. Woody hard texture. Diagnostic combination.
Growth rings: ANNUAL RINGS visible in bracket cross-section. Each ring one growing season. Can estimate minimum age. Old brackets may be 30-50+ years.
Assessment: WHITE ROT indicates progressive structural loss. SLOW PROGRESSION - May take decades to cause critical weakness. SHELL THICKNESS assessment if decay extensive. Measure residual sound wood. LOCATION MATTERS - Decay in buttress or root collar more concerning than high branches.
Management: SLOW DISEASE - Often can retain for extended period with monitoring. RE-ASSESS PERIODICALLY - Every 2-5 years. Check decay progression. REDUCE LOADING if necessary - Crown reduction buys time. REMOVE if over critical targets and decay extensive.
Similar fungi: FOMES FOMENTARIUS - Hoof-shaped grey brackets. But primary hosts are beech birch not willow. Different host preference. GANODERMA - Brown brackets. Zonate. White rot but different appearance and hosts. INONOTUS - Various species. Some similar but Phellinus on willow distinctive.
Willow ecology: RIPARIAN HABITAT - Willows along watercourses. Phellinus common. POLLARDED WILLOWS - Traditional management. Old pollards often have Phellinus. Part of veteran willow ecology. DECLINE TRAJECTORY - Infected willows decline slowly over decades. Deadwood creation. Saproxylic habitat value.
Conservation: OLD WILLOWS with Phellinus have ecological value. Veteran status. Deadwood habitat. Retain where safe.
Prognosis: SLOW PROGRESSION - Willow may live for decades with Phellinus. VETERAN STATUS common - Old pollarded willows often infected. Part of natural aging. MANAGEMENT BALANCES ecology value vs safety risk

question: Torsion scar spiraling upwards around trunk with cambial tearing indicates:
optionB: Historic torsional wind load or mechanical stress
learn: Spiral scars result from torsional (twisting) forces caused by complex wind loading or mechanical impact - cambium torn in spiral pattern
whyMatters: Crown catches wind differentially creating torque. Stem twists. Cambium tears in spiral along grain. Historic injury that may have healed. Indicates significant loading event
deepDive:
Torsional loading effects: MECHANISM - Complex wind loading creates torque on tree. Crown sections move differently. Stem twists. Bark and cambium tear along spiral path following grain.
APPEARANCE - Spiral scar or crack ascending trunk. May be healed (old injury with callus) or fresh. Bark torn/missing along spiral line.
GRAIN PATTERN - Follows wood grain spiral. May complete one or more turns up stem.
HISTORIC vs RECENT - Old scars callused over wood dark. Recent scars fresh wood exposed bark edges sharp.
Causes: SEVERE STORMS - Violent twisting winds. Tornado microburst severe gust. Generates torsion exceeding tissue strength. MECHANICAL IMPACT - Tree strike (another tree falling). Vehicle impact. Construction equipment. Can create torsional forces. CROWN LOADING - Heavy asymmetric crown. Wind catches crown creates torque. Especially if crown unbalanced.
Species variation: SPECIES WITH SPIRAL GRAIN more vulnerable - Sweet chestnut commonly has spiral grain. Torsion follows grain pattern. FLEXIBLE WOOD - Can twist more before breaking. May show torsion scars more readily than rigid wood that snaps.
Assessment: DOCUMENT SCAR - Measure length note spiral pattern fresh vs old. EVALUATE STRUCTURAL IMPACT - How much circumference affected? Depth of injury? Cambium still alive around injury? LOOK FOR ASSOCIATED DAMAGE - Cracks nearby. Decay colonizing scar. Root damage (if impact event). LOADING - Has cause been removed or does risk continue?
Management: OLD HEALED SCARS - Usually LOW RISK if well-callused. Tree compartmentalized. Monitor. FRESH SCARS - MODERATE to HIGH RISK depending on extent. Fresh cambial damage. May allow decay entry. Assess healing response. EXTENSIVE SCARS - Large percentage of circumference. May compromise structural integrity. REDUCE LOADING if retention considered - Crown reduction especially asymmetric crown.
Prognosis: HEALING ABILITY depends on extent of damage. Localized torsion scars usually heal. Extensive damage may not. Tree may survive for years with torsion scar but may be weakened.
Comparison: TORSION SCAR (spiral) different from LONGITUDINAL CRACK (vertical). Different loading patterns. Both indicate significant stress but spiral indicates TORSIONAL load specifically.
Recognition: SPIRAL PATTERN ascending trunk DISTINCTIVE. Follows grain. May complete turns. Unlike vertical cracks.
Follow-up: If fresh torsion scar monitor healing. Re-assess annually. Check for crack propagation decay entry structural compromise. If old stable scar monitor periodically confirm no progression

question: Dead standing birch with thick grey hoof-shaped perennial bracket - which species?
optionB: Armillaria mellea
learn: Fomes fomentarius forms large grey hoof-shaped perennial brackets on dead birch and causes white rot
whyMatters: Classic hoof fungus or tinder fungus. Large woody brackets. Grey appearance. Perennial. Grows on dead birch primarily. Historic uses as tinder. Saproxylic species
deepDive:
Fomes fomentarius: COMMON NAME - Hoof fungus Tinder fungus Tinder polypore.
HOSTS - Birch (Betula) primary. Also beech occasionally other hardwoods. Usually on DEAD standing trees or fallen logs.
BRACKETS - Large hoof-shaped 10-40cm wide 10-20cm thick. Perennial hard woody. Upper surface GREY smooth to lumpy. Concentric zones. Pore surface grey-brown to cream.
TEXTURE - Very hard woody. Can be almost rock-like in old specimens.
LOCATION - On dead standing birch trunks. Occasionally on dead branches.
DECAY - White rot. Breaks down deadwood. Saproxylic decomposer.
GROWTH - Slow-growing. Adds layers annually. Old brackets may be 30+ years old.
ANNUAL RINGS - Visible in cross-section. Can count rings to estimate age.
Historical uses: TINDER - Inner tissue used historically to catch sparks for fire starting. Prepared by beating and treating. Hence 'tinder fungus'. AMADOU - Prepared fungal material. Fly fishing lure material. Traditional uses. MEDICINAL - Various traditional medicinal claims. Research ongoing.
Ecological role: DEADWOOD DECOMPOSER - Important saproxylic fungus. Breaks down dead birch. Part of forest ecosystem. HABITAT - Bracket itself provides habitat. Invertebrates cavity nesters. INDICATOR - Presence indicates deadwood quality. Old-growth forest indicator in some regions.
Recognition: LARGE GREY HOOF-SHAPED bracket on DEAD BIRCH equals Fomes fomentarius. Characteristic appearance.
Similar species: PHELLINUS - Darker grey-black. Different hosts (willow). F. fomentarius paler grey. PIPTOPORUS BETULINUS - Birch polypore. Annual bracket. White when fresh brown when old. Rounded not hoof-shaped. GANODERMA - Brown brackets. Zonate. White spore deposit. Different appearance.
Management implications: SAPROPHYTIC - Only on dead wood. Not a pathogen of living trees. NO CONCERN for tree health if found on dead standing tree. DEADWOOD VALUE - Indicates quality deadwood habitat. Consider retaining dead trees with Fomes where safe.
Conservation: Old brackets on veteran dead trees have biodiversity value. Part of saproxylic community. Protection of deadwood habitat includes protecting Fomes populations.
Standing dead birch: Common in woodlands. Fomes fomentarius very common on dead birch in UK. Natural succession. Part of birch ecology.
Cultural interest: 'Iceman' Ötzi carried Fomes fomentarius. Prehistoric use. Long human association. Fascinating cultural artifact

question: Hawthorn (Crataegus monogyna) is distinguished in winter by:
optionB: Thorns on twigs and small alternate buds
learn: Hawthorn has distinctive thorns (modified side shoots) on twigs plus small alternate buds - unmistakable winter ID
whyMatters: Common native shrub or small tree. Thorns sharp and woody. Common in hedgerows. Small red buds alternate. Dense branching
deepDive:
Hawthorn winter ID: THORNS - Sharp woody spines on twigs. 1-3cm long. Modified side shoots. DIAGNOSTIC feature.
BUDS - Alternate arrangement small 2-4mm rounded red-brown.
TWIGS - Dense branching pattern. Grey-brown. Thorns at leaf nodes.
BARK - Grey-brown scaly flaking. Develops fissures with age.
FORM - Shrub or small tree. Often dense rounded crown. Common in hedgerows field boundaries.
BERRIES - Red haws (berries) often persist into winter. Small rounded. Birds feed on them.
Key identification: THORNS definitive. Only a few UK trees/shrubs have thorns. Hawthorn most common. ALTERNATE BUDS - Not opposite. DENSE BRANCHING - Thorny thicket appearance.
Native status: NATIVE - Common hawthorn (Crataegus monogyna). Widespread UK. HEDGEROW SPECIES - Historically planted for stock-proof hedging. Thorns deter livestock. ANCIENT WOODLAND INDICATOR - In some contexts. Long-established woodlands.
Similar species with thorns: BLACKTHORN (Prunus spinosa) - Also thorny. But thorns on side shoots pointing sideways. Buds often clustered. Black bark when wet. Flowers earlier (white blossom March-April before leaves). PYRACANTHA (Firethorn) - Ornamental shrub. Thorny. Not native. Orange or red berries. Different appearance. FEW OTHER UK NATIVES have thorns. Hawthorn and blackthorn main thorny hedgerow species.
Recognition: THORNS on twigs SMALL RED BUDS equals hawthorn or blackthorn. Distinguish: HAWTHORN - Thorns shorter branching more open buds reddish. BLACKTHORN - Thorns longer more horizontal bark very dark when wet forms dense thickets.
Cultural importance: TRADITIONAL HEDGING - Living fences. Stock control. FOLKLORE - Fairies associated with hawthorn. May Day traditions. WILDLIFE VALUE - Berries for birds. Dense thorny cover for nesting. Important native species.
Flowers: LATE SPRING blossom May-June. White flowers strong scent. After leaf emergence. Distinctive.
Summer leaves: LOBED LEAVES deeply cut. 3-7 lobes. Variable. Not visible in winter. Leaf shape helps ID in growing season.
Management: HEDGEROW MAINTENANCE - Traditionally laid (pleached). Also trimmed. LANDSCAPE VALUE - Screening wildlife habitat. THORNS - Caution when working near hawthorn. Sharp hazard

question: Dead beech with thin grey crust showing black marginal lines on bark - which fungus?
optionB: Stereum gausapatum
learn: Stereum gausapatum forms thin leathery crust with distinctive black zone lines on dead beech and causes white rot
whyMatters: Common on dead beech. Thin leathery brackets or crust. Black lines diagnostic. White rot decomposer. Saproxylic species
deepDive:
Stereum gausapatum: HOSTS - Beech (Fagus) primary. Dead wood primarily. Occasionally on other hardwoods.
APPEARANCE - Thin 2-5mm leathery crust or shelf-like brackets. Upper surface grey-brown hairy zoned.
UNDERSURFACE - Smooth (not pores or gills). Grey to brown. May show purple tints when fresh.
DISTINCTIVE FEATURE - BLACK ZONE LINES visible in wood beneath fungus. Dark lines demarcating zones. Diagnostic.
TEXTURE - Leathery flexible. Persists on dead wood.
DECAY - White rot. Breaks down dead beech wood. Saprophytic.
OCCURRENCE - Common on dead standing beech fallen beech logs branches. Often extensive patches.
Black zone lines: PSEUDOSCLEROTIAL LINES - Black pigmented fungal structures in wood. Visible as dark lines. Demarcate fungal territory. Species-specific pattern. DIAGNOSTIC FEATURE - Black lines in beech wood beneath grey stereum crust equals S. gausapatum. Characteristic.
Ecological role: DEADWOOD DECOMPOSER - Important saproxylic fungus on beech deadwood. Part of decomposition succession. HABITAT CREATION - Deadwood with Stereum provides habitat. Invertebrates other fungi.
Recognition: THIN GREY HAIRY CRUST on DEAD BEECH plus BLACK ZONE LINES equals S. gausapatum. Combination diagnostic.
Similar Stereum species: STEREUM HIRSUTUM - Common on many hardwoods. Orange-yellow underside. No distinct black zone lines. Different. STEREUM RUGOSUM - Bleeding broadleaf crust. 'Bleeds' red liquid when scratched. Different species. STEREUM SUBTOMENTOSUM - On oak. Different host. S. GAUSAPATUM - Beech-specific black zone lines diagnostic.
Saproxylic community: Stereum part of complex fungal community on deadwood. Interacts with other species. Zone lines may represent competition zones between different fungi.
Management implications: SAPROPHYTIC - On dead wood only. No concern for living tree health. DEADWOOD VALUE - Indicates quality deadwood. Ecological value. Consider retaining dead beech where safe. Habitat protection.
Conservation: Deadwood specialist. Dependent on deadwood habitat. Protection of veteran and standing dead beech protects S. gausapatum and associated biodiversity.
Field observation: Very common on dead beech. Easy to find in beech woodlands. Examination of deadwood substrate shows black zone lines clearly. Interesting pattern

question: Pronounced buttressing with hollow sound behind ribs suggests:
optionB: Adaptive growth masking internal decay
learn: Trees develop buttressing to compensate for internal weaknesses - hollow sound proves cavity or decay beneath external reinforcement
whyMatters: Tree adds wood externally where stress highest to compensate for internal decay. External appearance may look impressive while internal structure compromised
deepDive:
Compensatory buttressing assessment: MECHANISM - Tree detects stress. Internal decay reduces strength. Tree adds wood externally to compensate. Buttressing forms around weak area.
EXTERNAL APPEARANCE - Impressive pronounced ribs and flanges. Looks structurally strong.
INTERNAL REALITY - Cavity or extensive decay beneath buttresses. Hollow sound when buttress sounded.
ACOUSTIC TESTING - Tap or sound buttress with mallet. HOLLOW SOUND indicates cavity beneath. SOLID SOUND indicates sound wood.
Implications: COMPENSATION SUCCESS is POSITIVE - Tree IS responding. Has vigor to add wood. Successfully managing internal decay. DECAY EXTENT may be GREATER than external appearance suggests. Buttressing masks internal condition. ASSESSMENT REQUIRES probing sounding internal examination. Cannot judge by external buttressing alone.
Risk evaluation: ADEQUATE COMPENSATION - If buttressing substantial and hollow not too extensive may be structurally adequate. Shell thickness critical. INADEQUATE COMPENSATION - If decay extensive or progressing compensation may not maintain strength. FAILURE MODES - Consider if buttress itself could fail (peel away). Or if entire section could collapse.
Assessment methods: SOUNDING - Tap buttresses and stem. Compare responses. Locate hollow zones. PROBING - Increment borer resistograph through buttress. Determine shell thickness and cavity extent. TOMOGRAPHY - If high-value tree. Image internal structure. Quantify decay. EXCAVATION - Expose root buttresses. Examine base for decay. VISUAL - Openings cracks in buttresses. Clues to internal condition.
Management: QUANTIFY EXTENT - Don't assume buttressing equals safety. Measure actual shell thickness. SHELL THICKNESS RATIO (t/R) - Critical factor. Greater than 0.3 generally adequate. Less than 0.3 concerning. COMPENSATORY GROWTH - Positive sign but doesn't eliminate risk. Tree trying to manage. ADEQUATE or INADEQUATE compensation? LOAD REDUCTION - Crown reduction can extend safe life if compensation marginally adequate. MONITORING - Re-assess periodically. Check for progression.
Veteran tree context: Ancient trees often show pronounced buttressing over extensive internal cavities. Part of veteran tree character. May be structurally adequate despite hollowness. ACCEPT HIGHER RISK if ecological value warrants and targets allow. Each case individual.
Engineering principle: SECTION MODULUS depends on distribution of material. External shell carries load even with hollow center. BUT if shell too thin or discontinuous failure occurs. Buttressing attempts to maintain section modulus despite internal losses. Success variable

question: Decayed fallen beech limb with tough black stromata shaped like dead man's fingers - identify:
optionB: Ganoderma applanatum
learn: Xylaria polymorpha produces distinctive club-shaped black stromata (fruiting bodies) resembling dead man's fingers on deadwood
whyMatters: Saprophytic on dead wood. Distinctive appearance. Black stromata. Club or finger-shaped. Common on beech. White rot decomposer
deepDive:
Xylaria polymorpha: COMMON NAME - Dead man's fingers Dead moll's fingers (older name).
HOSTS - Various hardwoods. Beech especially common. Dead wood primarily. Fallen logs stumps dead branches.
STROMATA - Club-shaped or finger-like. 3-10cm tall 1-3cm thick. BLACK exterior with white interior when fresh. Tough leathery texture. Multiple fingers clustered at base.
APPEARANCE - Resembles black fingers emerging from wood. Eerie appearance gives common name.
DECAY - White rot. Saproxylic decomposer. Breaks down dead hardwood.
LIFECYCLE - Stromata are sexual stage (teleomorph). Contain embedded perithecia with ascospores.
OCCURRENCE - Common on deadwood in woodlands. Autumn primarily but stromata persist.
Ecological role: DEADWOOD BREAKDOWN - Key saproxylic species. Cellulose and lignin degradation. SUCCESSION - Early-middle colonizer in deadwood succession. HABITAT - Stromata provide microhabitat. Invertebrates shelter feeding.
Recognition: BLACK CLUB-SHAPED FINGERS emerging from DEADWOOD equals X. polymorpha. Distinctive appearance unmistakable.
Similar species: XYLARIA HYPOXYLON - Candlesnuff fungus. Thinner more delicate. Branched antler-like. Different appearance. XYLARIA LONGIPES - Longer stalk. Less club-shaped. Less common. X. POLYMORPHA - Thick fingers. Most common and distinctive.
Management implications: SAPROPHYTIC - On dead wood only. No concern for living trees. DEADWOOD INDICATOR - Presence confirms quality deadwood habitat. RETAIN deadwood with Xylaria where safe.
Conservation: Saproxylic species. Part of deadwood community. Dependent on deadwood habitat availability. Protection of deadwood protects Xylaria and associated fauna.
Cultural interest: DISTINCTIVE APPEARANCE - Memorable. Educational value. FOLKLORE - Eerie appearance. Associated with dead wood (appropriate habitat). PHOTOGRAPHY - Popular subject for nature photography. Striking appearance.
Field observation: Easy to spot. Common on beech. Look on fallen logs dead standing trees. Autumn best but persists into winter. Worthwhile identification - very distinctive.
Related species: Xylaria genus - various species on deadwood. X. polymorpha most conspicuous and common in UK. Candlesnuff (X. hypoxylon) also common but smaller more delicate

question: Hazel (Corylus avellana) is distinguished in winter by:
optionB: Rounded downy buds on zigzag twigs
learn: Hazel has small rounded buds with downy (hairy) covering arranged alternately on slender zigzag twigs
whyMatters: Already covered in Q95. Hazel features: alternate small rounded downy buds zigzag twigs male catkins (lambs tails) in winter. Native shrub/small tree. See Q95 for full details
deepDive:
Hazel winter ID - Q95 reference: See Q95 for complete description.
Key features: BUDS - Small 3-6mm rounded DOWNY alternate. TWIGS - Slender ZIGZAG pattern. CATKINS - Long pendulous yellow catkins visible late winter. BARK - Smooth grey-brown with horizontal lenticels. FORM - Multi-stemmed shrub or small tree. NUTS - Hazelnuts distinctive (autumn).
Native coppiced species. Q95 has full details of ID confusion species cultural significance. Refer to Q95 for comprehensive information

question: Ash with yellow-brown bracket with prominent hairs and upper stem white rot - which fungus?
optionB: Inonotus hispidus
learn: Inonotus hispidus causes white rot of ash and produces distinctive hairy yellow-brown brackets on trunks and branches
whyMatters: Very hairy (hispid) brackets. Yellow-brown to rust colored. On ash primarily. Also occasional on other hardwoods. Brittle white rot
deepDive:
Inonotus hispidus: COMMON NAME - Shaggy bracket Hispid bracket.
HOSTS - Ash (Fraxinus excelsior) primary UK host. Also apple walnut mulberry London plane occasionally. HOST-SPECIFIC generally.
BRACKETS - Annual. Appear late summer-autumn. 10-30cm wide.
DISTINCTIVE FEATURE - VERY HAIRY upper surface. Long rust-brown hairs (hispid). Hence species name. Yellow-brown to rust colored. Hairy appearance diagnostic.
PORE SURFACE - Yellow-brown. Bruises darker.
LOCATION - On trunks and branches. Often mid-height or higher. Occasionally basal.
DECAY TYPE - White rot. Brittle friable texture. Advances relatively quickly. Wood becomes pale and crumbly.
FAILURE MODE - Branch failure or stem snap. Brittle decay. Sudden failure possible.
CONTEXT - Often on stressed ash. Ash dieback creates opportunities. Stressed trees more vulnerable.
Identification: VERY HAIRY appearance YELLOW-BROWN color ASH host. Combination diagnostic. No other common UK fungus looks like this.
Recognition: If you see SHAGGY HAIRY bracket on ASH it is I. hispidus. Unmistakable once seen.
Assessment: WHITE ROT progressing. BRITTLE nature of decay concerning. Sudden failure possible. LOCATION - If high in tree assess drop zone. Branch failure risk. If basal assess windthrow potential. STRESS INDICATOR - Ash with I. hispidus likely stressed. Check for other issues (ash dieback other stresses).
Management: ASH DIEBACK CONTEXT - I. hispidus increasingly common on dieback-affected ash. Secondary pathogen on weakened trees. DECAY PROGRESSION - Relatively fast for white rot. Re-assess frequently. REMOVAL often necessary especially over targets. Brittle decay reduces reliability. REDUCE LOADING - Crown reduction may extend safe life marginally.
Similar species (none really similar): Inonotus hispidus distinctive. VERY HAIRY appearance unlike other common brackets. RUST-BROWN color. ASH HOST. Unmistakable.
Historical note: Often found on ASH THAT APPEARS HEALTHY. Hidden internal decay. Bracket indicates decay already established. Assess promptly

question: Large limb showing tension crack on upper side with rolled callus indicates:
optionB: Historic overloading with partial healing
learn: Tension cracks form on the upper (tension) side of loaded limbs - callus formation shows tree attempted healing but crack indicates significant historic loading event
whyMatters: Bending loads place upper side in tension. Crack formed during overload event. Tree produced callus attempting to close crack. Successful compartmentalization attempt. Historic injury
deepDive:
Tension crack assessment: LOCATION - UPPER SIDE of branch or limb. Tension side during bending loads.
ORIENTATION - Typically perpendicular to branch axis. Crack opens when branch loaded.
CALLUS - Rolled callus tissue at crack edges. Wound wood attempting to close crack over years.
EXTENT - May be partially closed by callus. Or still open with gap visible.
AGE - Old cracks well-callused. Recent cracks have minimal callus.
Mechanism: OVERLOAD EVENT - Storm wind heavy loading (snow ice). Branch bent beyond elastic limit. Wood fibers failed in tension. Crack formed. PARTIAL FAILURE - Crack did not propagate completely through branch. Partial failure arrested. HEALING RESPONSE - Cambium produced callus attempting closure and compartmentalization.
Risk assessment: HISTORIC EVENT - If crack well-callused and no recent extension LOW to MODERATE risk. Stable old injury. ACTIVE PROPAGATION - If crack extending (fresh wood visible) HIGH RISK. Progressive failure. EXTENT - How deep is crack? Percentage of cross-section affected? Shallow surface cracks less concerning than deep cracks. LOCATION ON LIMB - Cracks near union more concerning than mid-limb. Stress concentration.
Management: OLD STABLE CRACKS - Monitor periodically. Check for extension. Photograph for comparison. ACTIVE CRACKS - Reduce loading (limb reduction). Or remove limb if over targets. LARGE LIMBS - More concerning. Higher mass increases forces. FAILURE MODE - Expect failure at crack location if progression continues. Drop zone consideration.
Assessment protocol: DOCUMENT - Measure crack length depth. Photograph showing callus and extent. COMPARE - To previous inspections if available. Has crack extended? PROBE - Gently check if crack opens with hand pressure (if safe to approach). Active movement concerning. LOADING - Assess crown weight above crack. Heavy foliage snow ice increases stress.
Callus interpretation: GOOD CALLUS FORMATION indicates tree vigor and successful compartmentalization. Positive. MINIMAL CALLUS on old injury indicates poor response. Tree stressed or declining. Concerning.
Comparison: TENSION CRACKS on upper side. COMPRESSION CRACKS on lower side (less common). Shear cracks in unions (different pattern). Each indicates different loading mode and failure mechanism

question: Small tree with oyster-shaped pale brackets in tiers on trunk - which fungus?
optionB: Inonotus hispidus
learn: Pleurotus ostreatus (oyster mushroom) grows on deadwood or stressed trees producing pale oyster-shaped edible brackets in clusters
whyMatters: Edible mushroom. Grows on dead or dying wood. Clusters of pale brackets. White spore print. Saprophytic primarily. Common
deepDive:
Pleurotus ostreatus: COMMON NAME - Oyster mushroom Oyster fungus.
EDIBILITY - EDIBLE. Cultivated commercially. Wild specimens harvested. Popular culinary fungus.
HOSTS - Many hardwoods. Dead dying or stressed trees. Beech birch oak aspen ash others. Not host-specific.
APPEARANCE - Oyster or shell-shaped cap. 5-15cm wide. Pale cream white grey or light brown. Smooth surface. Short or no stem.
CLUSTERS - Multiple brackets in tiers or overlapping groups. Shelving appearance.
GILLS - White to cream. Decurrent (running down stem if present). White spore print.
TIMING - Autumn to early winter primarily. Cool temperatures. After rain.
DECAY - White rot. Saproxylic. Breaks down deadwood. Occasionally parasitic on stressed living trees.
Role: SAPROPHYTIC primarily - Dead trees stumps logs fallen branches. OCCASIONAL PARASITE - Stressed or dying living trees. Rarely on vigorous trees. EDIBLE - Safe to eat. Cultivated. Wild foraging popular (with proper ID).
Recognition: OYSTER-SHAPED pale CLUSTERS white GILLS equals Pleurotus ostreatus. Distinctive appearance.
Culinary note: Mild flavor. Used in cooking. Cultivation easy. Commercial production. Wild specimens free food if correctly identified.
Safety: PROPER IDENTIFICATION essential. Similar species exist. If uncertain don't eat. COOK THOROUGHLY. Some people sensitive to raw oyster mushrooms.
Management implications: DEADWOOD - Usually indicates dead or dying substrate. Assess tree vitality. If on living tree evaluate health status. NOT A PRIMARY PATHOGEN - Opportunistic on stressed wood. Rarely kills healthy trees. More likely colonizing already declining tissue. SAPROPHYTIC VALUE - Breaks down deadwood. Ecological role.
Similar species: PLEUROTUS PULMONARIUS - Pale oyster. Spring-summer fruiting. Similar appearance. PLEUROTUS CORNUCOPIAE - Branched oyster. Less common. ANGEL WINGS (Pleurocybella) - Smaller. Different habitat. Caution with ID if foraging.
Cultural importance: FORAGED - Traditional and modern foraging. Free food. CULTIVATED - Easy to grow. Commercial and home cultivation. Logs sawdust. CULINARY - Popular ingredient. Asian cuisine. Widespread use.
Ecological: Deadwood recycler. Part of saproxylic community. Contributes to nutrient cycling

question: Alder (Alnus glutinosa) is recognized in winter by:
optionB: Large opposite buds
optionC: Purple rounded buds on short stalks plus small cones
learn: Alder has distinctive purple to brown rounded buds on short stalks alternate arrangement and small woody cones persisting from previous year
whyMatters: Native riparian tree. Buds purple alternate. Male catkins visible in winter. Female cones persist. Nitrogen-fixing. Common near water
deepDive:
Alder winter ID: BUDS - Alternate arrangement. Rounded 4-7mm purple to reddish-brown. On SHORT STALKS (pedicels). Distinctive feature.
CONES - Small woody 1-2cm cone-like female catkins persist from previous year. Dark brown. Distinctive.
CATKINS - Male catkins present in winter. Pendulous 5-10cm yellow-brown. Elongate and release pollen early spring.
TWIGS - Dark purple-brown. Often slightly sticky.
BARK - Dark grey-brown fissured in mature trees. Smooth when young. Orange inner bark visible if scraped.
FORM - Medium tree. Often near water. Rounded crown.
Key features: PURPLE BUDS on STALKS diagnostic. Short pedicels unique among UK trees. SMALL CONES persistent. Woody cone-like structures.
Habitat: RIPARIAN - Riverbanks streams wet ground. Tolerates waterlogging. NITROGEN-FIXING - Root nodules with Frankia bacteria. Enriches soil. PIONEER - Colonizes wet disturbed ground.
Native ecology: NATIVE TREE - Important in UK ecology. ALDERS critical for riparian stability. Bank stabilization. WILDLIFE VALUE - Seeds for birds. Deadwood habitat.
Similar species (none close): BIRCH - Also has catkins. But buds different (pointed not rounded). Bark different (white or silver). NO PERSISTENT CONES. HAZEL - Has catkins. Buds rounded but on twigs not stalks. NO CONES. Alder buds on stalks and cones together diagnostic.
Recognition: PURPLE ROUNDED BUDS on SHORT STALKS plus SMALL WOODY CONES equals alder. Near water habitat supports ID.
Conservation concern: PHYTOPHTHORA ALNI - Alder Phytophthora disease devastating. See Q134. Bleeding cankers. Riparian alders declining. Threat to species. Monitor alder health.
Cultural uses: WOOD - Historically used for underwater construction. Doesn't rot in water. Piles foundations. CHARCOAL - Produces quality charcoal. Traditional use. DYEING - Bark used for dyes. Traditional crafts.
Seasonal: EARLY POLLEN - Male catkins release pollen February-March. Early pollen source. Female flowers small red upright develop into cones

question: Wedge-shaped decay column in cross-section with sharp boundaries indicates:
optionB: Successful CODIT compartmentalization
learn: Shell thickness ratio is critical - adequate shell can maintain strength despite central cavity if uniform and without openings
whyMatters: The outer shell carries most bending load. If shell is thick enough continuous and sound the tree can remain stable for decades despite large central cavity
deepDive:
CODIT compartmentalization: CODIT MODEL - Dr. Alex Shigo's 4-wall system isolating injured tissue. Wall 1 plugs vessels vertically (weakest). Wall 2 resists inward radial spread (stronger). Wall 3 resists lateral tangential spread (strongest). Wall 4 barrier zone formed after injury (effectiveness varies by species and wound).
Wedge-shaped pattern: Walls 1-3 create wedge-shaped decay column when successful. Sharp boundaries between sound and decayed wood. Decay contained within defined zone.
Successful containment: Demonstrates tree vigor and effective compartmentalization response. Decay is NOT progressing beyond wedge boundaries. Tree has successfully arrested spread.
Sound wood outside wedge: Functional structural wood remains outside decay column. Tree maintains adequate strength if shell thickness sufficient.
Assessment protocol: Measure sound wood shell outside wedge at multiple radii. Calculate shell thickness-to-radius ratio (t/R). Check wedge extent - what percentage of cross-section affected? Verify barrier integrity - are walls intact with no breaches?
Shell adequacy: If t/R greater than 0.3 and barriers intact, tree often structurally adequate despite wedge-shaped decay. If shell adequate and decay truly contained, retention may be appropriate.
Management: Successful CODIT often means RETAIN tree with monitoring. Decay contained and not progressing. Re-assess periodically to verify containment continues. Monitor shell thickness every 3-5 years.
Species variation: Oak excellent compartmentalizer - sharp wedge boundaries common. Beech poor compartmentalizer - fuzzy boundaries, decay spreads. Poplar/willow intermediate. Species-specific expectations critical for assessment.

question: Dead ash with thick black crusty patches on bark revealing sooty material beneath - which fungus?
optionB: Inonotus hispidus
learn: Kretzschmaria deusta produces distinctive black crusty stromata on dead or dying ash and causes extremely brittle ceramic-like decay
whyMatters: Already detailed in Q6 but specific to ash here. Black crusty patches diagnostic. Sooty material beneath crust. Extreme brittleness. See Q6 for full details
deepDive:
Kretzschmaria deusta on ash: See Q6 for comprehensive details.
Key features: APPEARANCE - Grey powdery patches initially. Turn black crusty. Sooty material beneath. HOSTS - Beech primary. ASH secondary especially ash affected by ash dieback. Sycamore horse chestnut. DECAY TYPE - Soft rot causing unique BRITTLE CERAMIC-LIKE fracture. DANGER - Extensive internal decay minimal external signs. SUDDEN CATASTROPHIC failure.
Ash dieback context: ASH WEAKENED by dieback highly vulnerable to K. deusta. Secondary pathogen on stressed dying ash. Combined effect devastating. INCREASED INCIDENCE on ash with spread of ash dieback. Deadly combination.
Assessment: EXTREMELY HIGH RISK. Assume extensive internal decay if black stromata present. Conservative assessment essential. REMOVAL usually necessary. Brittleness means sudden failure.
See Q6 for full assessment protocols management details. This question emphasizes ASH HOST context

question: Elm (Ulmus spp.) is identified in winter by:
optionB: Asymmetrical leaf scars and slender zig-zag twigs
learn: Elm has alternate buds asymmetrical leaf scars and characteristic zig-zag twig growth pattern
whyMatters: English elm wych elm several species. Alternate buds. Leaf scars uneven. Twigs zig-zag. Often suckering from roots
deepDive:
Elm winter ID: BUDS - Alternate arrangement small 3-5mm pointed red-brown scales. Slightly hairy or smooth depending on species.
LEAF SCARS - ASYMMETRICAL. One side of scar higher than other. Distinctive feature. Located below buds.
TWIGS - SLENDER ZIG-ZAG pattern. Not straight. Angles at buds.
BARK - Rough fissured grey-brown. Develops deep furrows with age.
FORM - Variable. English elm tall with suckers. Wych elm spreading.
Species differences: ENGLISH ELM (Ulmus procera) - Tall narrow crown. Suckering habit. Rare now due to Dutch elm disease. WYCH ELM (Ulmus glabra) - Spreading crown. No suckers. Native. Larger leaves in summer. DUTCH ELM - Hybrids and cultivars. Various forms.
Key diagnostic features: ASYMMETRICAL LEAF SCARS diagnostic. Check carefully. One side higher. ZIG-ZAG TWIGS common in elms. Not unique but supports ID.
Dutch elm disease context: DEVASTATED UK elm populations 1960s-1980s. Fungus spread by bark beetles. Most mature elms killed. SUCKERS PERSIST - English elm suckers still common. Grow until disease strikes again. WYCH ELM - More resistant in some cases. Native species still present.
Recognition: ALTERNATE BUDS plus ASYMMETRICAL LEAF SCARS plus ZIG-ZAG TWIGS equals elm. Asymmetry of scars key feature.
Similar species: HAZEL - Also has zig-zag twigs. But buds rounded downy. Leaf scars symmetrical. Catkins present. HORNBEAM - Zig-zag twigs. But buds pressed close to twig. Leaf scars symmetrical. Fluted bark.
Cultural importance: HISTORICALLY IMPORTANT - Elm landscape trees. Avenue trees. Hedgerows. DISEASE LOSS - Landscape character changed by Dutch elm disease. Mature elms now rare. CONSERVATION - Efforts to find and propagate resistant clones. Research ongoing.
Summer features: LEAVES - Asymmetrical leaf base (one side joins petiole higher than other). Rough texture. Double-serrated margins. Leaf asymmetry famous elm characteristic.
Field identification: ASYMMETRICAL LEAF SCARS plus habitat context (hedgerows field boundaries especially with suckering stems) suggests elm

question: Oak with small iron-grey bracket at base causing heart rot - genus?
optionB: Ganoderma
learn: Ustulina deusta (now reclassified to Kretzschmaria) causes oak decline with iron-grey young stage before turning black
whyMatters: Historical name Ustulina deusta - same fungus as Kretzschmaria deusta covered in Q6. Taxonomy changed. Young stage grey before mature black crust. See Q6
deepDive:
Ustulina deusta taxonomic note: HISTORICAL NAME - Ustulina deusta.
CURRENT NAME - Kretzschmaria deusta. Same fungus. Reclassified. Taxonomy updated.
GREY STAGE - Young immature state appears grey powdery. Later turns black crusty. TWO STAGES confuse identification. Both same fungus different ages.
See Q6 for full details: Kretzschmaria deusta = Ustulina deusta same species. BEECH primary host OAK secondary. SOFT ROT brittle ceramic-like failure. MINIMAL external symptoms until late. EXTREMELY DANGEROUS sudden failure.
Assessment management identical regardless of name used. Q6 has comprehensive information.
Recognition: GREY PATCHES at base turning BLACK crusty. Beech or oak host. Sooty material beneath surface. Extreme brittleness. Emergency priority assessment

question: Sweet chestnut with annual white cheese-like brackets at base causing white rot - identify:
optionB: Fistulina hepatica
learn: Fistulina hepatica (beefsteak fungus) produces distinctive tongue-shaped red-brown brackets on oak and sweet chestnut
whyMatters: Edible when young. Brackets bleed red juice when cut. Brown rot despite white appearance. Oak and sweet chestnut hosts. Weakens heartwood
deepDive:
Fistulina hepatica: COMMON NAME - Beefsteak fungus Ox tongue.
HOSTS - Oak primary sweet chestnut secondary. Occasionally other hardwoods.
BRACKETS - Annual tongue-shaped or shelf-like 10-30cm. Upper surface red-brown sticky when wet.
DISTINCTIVE - Bleeds RED JUICE when cut fresh. Looks like raw meat inside. Pore surface cream bruises brown.
TEXTURE - Soft when fresh becomes corky when dry. Rough upper surface.
TIMING - Late summer to autumn. Annual fruiting.
DECAY TYPE - Brown rot of heartwood despite fungal appearance. Causes characteristic brown cubical decay.
LOCATION - Usually at base or on lower stem. Sometimes on wounds.
EDIBILITY - EDIBLE when young. Sour taste raw better cooked. Traditional European food.
Recognition: RED-BROWN BRACKET that BLEEDS RED on OAK or SWEET CHESTNUT equals F. hepatica. Distinctive.
Assessment: BROWN ROT equals BRITTLE FAILURE risk. Internal heartwood decay. STEM FAILURE mode. Assess shell thickness. VETERAN TREES often harbor Fistulina for decades. Part of ancient oak ecology.
Management: SLOW PROGRESSION typically. MONITOR regularly. REMOVE if over high-value targets and decay extensive. VETERAN CONSIDERATIONS - Retain where safe. Ecological value.
Similar species: NONE really similar. Bleeding red juice when fresh DIAGNOSTIC. Oak/chestnut host supports ID.
Cultural interest: Traditional food in parts of Europe. Distinctive appearance memorable

question: Progressive opening of crack with marked gap increase over 6 months indicates:
optionB: Active failure requiring immediate intervention
learn: Rapid crack propagation proves active structural failure in progress - immediate assessment and action required
whyMatters: Growth of crack gap proves failure is progressive. Forces exceed material strength. Continued propagation likely. Imminent collapse possible
deepDive:
Progressive crack assessment: MEASUREMENT - Establish baseline gap width. Re-measure after defined period (weeks/months).
SIGNIFICANT INCREASE - Gap widening proves active propagation. Failure in progress.
RATE MATTERS - Fast progression (mm per week) versus slow (mm per year). Fast equals urgent.
MONITORING PROTOCOL - Install crack gauges or simple markers. Measure regularly. Document with photos.
Why cracks propagate: LOADING CONTINUES - Wind crown weight environmental stresses continue. MATERIAL FATIGUE - Repeated loading cycles weaken surrounding wood. STRESS CONCENTRATION - Crack tip focuses stress. Drives further propagation. DECAY COLONIZATION - Fungi enter crack. Accelerate weakening.
Management urgency: ACTIVE PROPAGATION equals EMERGENCY. Cannot predict when propagation reaches critical point. IMMEDIATE BARRIERS - Exclude targets from fall zone. URGENT SPECIALIST ASSESSMENT - Structural engineer arborist. REMOVAL PRIORITY - Usually necessary. Stabilization rarely reliable.
Risk factors: LARGE CRACK - Greater extent more concerning. CRITICAL LOCATION - Crack in high-stress zone or near union. LOADING - Heavy crown wind exposure increase propagation rate. BRITTLE WOOD - Species with low fracture toughness.
Monitoring inadequate: ACTIVE CRACKS cannot be safely monitored long-term. Progression rate may accelerate. Weather event may cause sudden failure. Action required not just observation.
Crack gauges: SIMPLE - Mark crack edges with paint or pins. Measure gap with calipers. COMMERCIAL - Crack monitoring gauges available. Precise measurement. TELL-TALES - Glass strips across crack break if movement occurs. Visual indicator.
Documentation: Photograph with measurement scale. Record date gap width location weather. Compare over time. Shows progression rate. Essential for risk assessment and legal defensibility

question: Birch with hard white hoof-shaped annual bracket causing brown rot - identify:
optionB: Fomes fomentarius
learn: Piptoporus betulinus (birch polypore) produces distinctive white to brown rounded brackets exclusively on birch
whyMatters: Birch-specific. Annual bracket. White when young brown when old. Rounded not hoof-shaped actually. Soft cork-like. Brown rot of deadwood
deepDive:
Piptoporus betulinus: COMMON NAME - Birch polypore Birch bracket Razor strop fungus.
HOST - Birch ONLY (Betula spp). Highly host-specific. Will not grow on other trees.
BRACKETS - Annual semicircular to kidney-shaped 10-30cm. Upper surface WHITE to pale brown smooth. Pore surface white.
TEXTURE - Soft corky when fresh. Becomes hard when dry.
SHAPE - Rounded bulbous not truly hoof-shaped. Short thick stalk or sessile.
TIMING - Appear summer to autumn. Persist through winter.
DECAY - Brown rot of sapwood and heartwood. Attacks dead or dying birch.
ROLE - Primarily saprophytic. Colonizes dead standing birch or recently dead branches. Rarely parasitic.
Historical uses: RAZOR STROP - Dried fungus used to sharpen razors. Hence common name. TINDER - Can be used as tinder material for fire starting. MEDICINAL - Traditional uses. Modern research into bioactive compounds.
Host specificity: BIRCH ONLY. If you find this bracket it is 100% on birch. Useful diagnostic feature.
Recognition: WHITE to BROWN ROUNDED BRACKET on BIRCH equals P. betulinus. Cannot be anything else given host specificity.
Assessment: DEADWOOD INDICATOR - Usually on dead or dying birch. Check tree vitality. NOT A PRIMARY PATHOGEN - Opportunistic on stressed or dead wood. Indicates tree in decline or dead. REMOVE if hazardous. Birch likely declining or dead already.
